SubTopics: Write arguments to support claims with clear reasons, relevant evidence, and literary theory. Introduce claim(s), acknowledge alternate or opposing claims, and organize the reasons and evidence logically. Use accurate, credible sources.
Content: In the letter Adams informs her daughter about the experience of moving to a new city and living in a new home. Write an essay analyzing how Adams responds to her new surroundings. Use evidence from the letter to support your response.

:ibox:PLAN before you write
• Read the entire passage(s) carefully.

• Read the question carefully.

• Think about how the question relates to the passage(s).

• Organize your ideas on scratch paper. Use a thought map or outline to plan your essay.

• Plan to include multiple paragraphs in your essay.

FOCUS while you write
• Analyze and explain what you think about the information from the passage(s) in your essay.

• Support and develop the ideas in your essay by using text evidence from the passage(s).

• Use correct language, a variety of sentence types, and transitions between paragraphsin your essay.

• Organize your essay with an introduction, body, and conclusion.

SubTopics: Organization: Provide an introduction that creates suspense and anticipation for the reader. Structure of the text supports and clarifies the purpose and topic. Provide a concluding statement appropriate to the mode of writing.
Content: A student is writing a research paper about the Panama Canal. Read the paragraph from the research paper and answer the question that follows.

:ibox:The Panama Canal cuts through the country of Panama to connect the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. Before the canal was built, ships going from one ocean to another had to sail around the southernmost point of South America. This route added thousands of extra miles to the journey. The French beganbuilding the canal in the 1800s, and it was completed by the United States in 1914.
Which sentence would provide the BEST conclusion for the paragraph?

A.Choice: Building the Panama Canal proved to be a very difficult project.

B.Choice: The southern tip of South America is known as Cape Horn.

C.Choice: The finished canal was hailed as an engineering marvel.

D.Choice: Ships that use the Panama Canal carry different types of cargo.

SubTopics: Maintain consistency in style and tone.
Content: Read the sentence.
:ibox:Two weeks after Kelsey applied for a summer job bagging groceries, she received a call at the supermarket from the store's hiring manager.
What is the BEST way to rewrite this sentence for clarity?

A.Choice: Two weeks at the supermarket after Kelsey applied for a summer job bagging groceries, she received a call from the store's hiring manager.

B.Choice: Two weeks after Kelsey applied for a summer job bagging groceries, she received a call at the supermarket from the store's hiring manager at the supermarket.

C.Choice: Two weeks after Kelsey applied for a summer job bagging groceries at the supermarket, she received a call from the store's hiring manager.

D.Choice: Two weeks after Kelsey at the supermarket applied for a summer job bagging groceries, she received a call from the store's hiring manager.

SubTopics: Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources using search terms effectively, assess the credibility and accuracy of each source, quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.
Content: Which website would be most helpful to a student writing a report about plants that have adapted to thrive in a dry desert environment?

:ibox:Search: Desert Plants

Results: 1–4 of 200

A.Choice:
Desert Plants Varieties

Many people think of cacti when they hear the words “desert plants.” However, the desert is also home to beautiful flowers ...

B.Choice:
Desert Plants Watering

One of the best things about desert plants is that they do not need a lot of attention. Experts recommend ...

C.Choice:
Desert Plants Landscaping

Use desert plants to turn your yard into a one-of-a-kind showplace. Get the most popular ideas and designs for free ...

D.Choice:
Desert Plants Abilities

The desert is a harsh environment. Many desert plants have developed ways to cope with the lack of water ...

SubTopics: Analyze the main ideas and supporting details presented in diverse media and formats and explain how the ideas clarify a topic, text, or issue under study.
Content: According to the presentation, what are TWO tasks performed by horses and mules in World War I? Choose TWO answers.

SubTopics: Understand and evaluate a speaker's argument and specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the reasoning and the relevance and sufficiency of the evidence.
Content: How does the speaker support the claim that dogs “proved to be some of the best animal soldiers of all”?

A.Choice: by listing several different ways that dogs successfully assisted soldiers

B.Choice: by giving examples of specific dogs and the soldiers they were assigned to

C.Choice: by providing an expert's opinion about the usefulness of dogs in the war

D.Choice: by emphasizing that dogs were a soldier's first choice for carrying messages

SubTopics: Analyze the main ideas and supporting details presented in diverse media and formats and explain how the ideas clarify a topic, text, or issue under study.
Content: Which sentence from the presentation BEST expresses the main idea?

A.Choice: When you think about soldiers in World War I, chances are you imagine fighters with two legs, not four—and certainly no wings!

B.Choice: More than 16 million animals played key roles in World War I.

C.Choice: Horses, mules, and even camels were put to work on all types of battlefields during this time.

D.Choice: It may be difficult to imagine dogs being involved in the war, but they proved to be some of the best animal soldiers of all.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases, including figurative and connotative meanings. Analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning, tone, and mood, including words with multiple meanings within a text.
Content: In paragraph 8, what does the phrase “furrowed brows” suggest about Margot's sisters?

SubTopics: In literary texts, analyze how an author develops and contrasts the point of view, possible biases, and the perspectives of different characters or narrators.
Content: How does the author contrast Margot's point of view with her sisters' initial point of view about a stay-cation?

A.Choice: by explaining how the sisters' summer plans will conflict with Margot's idea for a stay-cation

B.Choice: by describing how the sisters react to Margot's attempt to convince them to have a stay-cation

C.Choice: by explaining how the sisters' school assignment makes them want to include their aunt in a stay-cation

D.Choice: by describing how the sisters oppose their parents' suggestion to turn their family trip into a stay-cation

SubTopics: Summarize texts, from a variety of genres, to determine a theme or central idea and analyze its development over the course of the text.
Content: THIS PROBLEM HAS TWO PARTS. FIRST, ANSWER PART A. THEN, ANSWER PART B.
Which sentence BEST expresses the theme of the passage?

A.Choice: People should always put work before play.

B.Choice: The best thing about summer is doing nothing.

C.Choice: A disappointment can lead to a fresh opportunity.

D.Choice: Doing things you have done before can still be fun.

Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: The sun on her face, the feeling of grass beneath her feet on a warm day, outdoor picnics, and homemade lemonade were just a few things that she looked forward to at the end of each school year.

B.Choice: This year, though, the beginning of May had come and gone, and it was already the first week of June.

C.Choice: Her dad informed her that her mother would be teaching summer courses at the local community college, and her aunt and uncle would be going on a vacation of their own to visit another relative in Washington, D.C.

D.Choice: It was not going to be the summer that Margot had originally hoped for, but she was looking forward to seeing what this new twist on a summer vacation would bring.

SubTopics: In informational texts, analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text, including how the sections contribute to the whole and to the development of themes or central ideas.
Content: How does the next-to-last paragraph most contribute to the development of an idea in the passage?

A.Choice: It describes the steps in the process of how the stones move.

B.Choice: It explains how scientists once viewed the reason for why the stones move.

C.Choice: It describes the features of the national park that contains the moving stones.

D.Choice: It explains how technology has been used to study the moving stones.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support an analysis of what the text says explicitly or implicitly and make logical inferences.
Content: Which sentence from the passage BEST supports the inference that advanced technology helped scientists solve the mystery of the moving stones?

A.Choice: Another common belief was that magnetic fields of Earth had moved the stones across the land.

B.Choice: Unfortunately, the scientists were never able to catch the stones in motion, so they could not prove their theory.

C.Choice: It was thought that Ralph Lorenz, a scientist with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, had finally found the answer in 2006 when he did an experiment in a lab.

D.Choice: Using cameras from a weather station and GPS tracking software, they discovered that the movement was not due to heavy winds or thick plots of ice.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support an analysis of what the text says explicitly or implicitly and make logical inferences.
Content: Using information from the passage, which steps are in the correct order to explain how the stones actually move across the desert?

A.Choice: Rocks get trapped in a sheet of ice. Ice forms on top of water. The rocks begin to slide. The wind blows. The sun warms up the ice.

B.Choice: Rocks get trapped in a sheet of ice. The sun warms up the ice. The wind blows. The rocks begin to slide. Ice forms on top of water.

C.Choice: Ice forms on top of water. Rocks get trapped in a sheet of ice. The sun warms up the ice. The wind blows. The rocks begin to slide.

D.Choice: The wind blows. The sun warms up the ice. The rocks begin to slide. Ice forms on top of water. Rocks get trapped in a sheet of ice.
